results.title: Fats
results.creator_credit: Michael Coyle and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Home Economics”.
This film stresses the correlation between heart disease and the consumption of fats and oils in the diet. Outlines ways in which the amount of fat and oil in the diet can be reduced.

results.title: Fathers of pop
results.creator_credit: Julian Cooper, Rodney Wilson and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: London in the 1950’s saw the beginnings of a ferment from which “the London Pop Scene” emerged in the sixties. Said to have begun with the Independent Group at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, one of its members at the time, Reyner Benham, reconstructs some of the events, attitudes and influences of the time and discusses with the survivors how it was then and how it looks now.

results.title: Fathers
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Discusses the role of the father in contemporary society. Previously the daily care of children was seen to be the mother’s responsibility, but an increasing number of fathers are now taking the primary responsibility for the care of their children. This active involvement by both parents with their children, could benefit all family members.

results.title: Father's footsteps
results.creator_credit: Erika Addis, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
80 year old Coffs Harbour identical twins Toni and Adelie Hurley travel to Antarctica on a voyage commemorating Ernest Shackleton’s ill-fated expedition of 1914-16. Their father, Australian director and cinematographer Frank Hurley, was the official photographer aboard the ‘Endurance’ which was crushed by ice as it approached Antarctica, leaving the entire crew stranded on the flows for 6 months. Forced to take to the open sea in 3 small boats when the ice broke, the crew eventually landed on uninhabited Elephant Island and remained there until Shackleton organised their rescue. Toni and Adelie recount their memories of their father as they return to the region where he struggled to survive. During their voyage, they discuss their father’s photographs and diary with Jonathon Shackleton, a relative of the Irish explorer, as they approach Elephant Island. Adelie Hurley also talks about her own career, and her status as Australia’s first female press photographer. Cinematography by Erika Addis. Edited by Tony Stevens. Narrated by Anne Phelan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Erika Addis, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films

results.title: Fate of a child
results.creator_credit: Leo Seltzer and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description: The death of a child is dramatised to show the living conditions in an under-developed area in Latin America. People surrounded by potential wealth live in poverty, starvation and ignorance. Technical assistance by the United Nations will help to eliminate the conditions responsible for the death of this child, through the economic development of such areas.
